topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Andy contrasts the common “arrogant doctor” pitch (problem-solution-brag) with a movie-inspired structure that starts with a world shift (old game to new game), previewing the strategic narrative concept.

topics.title: Podcast intro: Andy and strategic narrative
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Andy’s work helping CEOs align teams via a strategic narrative and previews topics like why problem-first pitching is less effective and how narratives align sales, marketing, product, fundraising, and hiring.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Coda and Lennysjobs.com/talent.

topics.title: Andy’s origin story: from coder to narrative
topics.summary: Andy recounts a failed VC pitch for his dot-com startup, discovering screenwriting books, and learning that story structure—not product changes—drove investor interest, eventually leading to consulting.

topics.title: Solving your own problem creates opportunities
topics.summary: They discuss how unexpected career paths emerge from solving personal problems and how “overnight success” is usually years in the making.

topics.title: Defining a strategic narrative and the old/new game
topics.summary: Andy defines strategic narrative as the CEO’s single guiding story for company alignment, contrasting the “arrogant doctor” pitch with a movement-based narrative that starts with a market shift (e.g., Salesforce and the cloud).

topics.title: Salesforce pitch: movement beats feature comparisons
topics.summary: They unpack how Salesforce could have pitched as “better CRM” but instead reframed the market as a paradigm shift (software to cloud), positioning incumbents as the old game.

topics.title: More examples: Zuora and Gong narratives
topics.summary: Andy shares Zuora’s “transactions to subscriptions” and Gong’s “opinions to reality” narratives, explaining how a movement frame can expand perception (e.g., Gong as a sales leadership tool, not just sales ops).

topics.title: Impact of Andy’s Zuora deck post and writing
topics.summary: Andy explains how his viral ‘Greatest Sales Deck’ post drove global inbound and validated that CEOs would pay for narrative work; they discuss the leverage of writing and distribution platforms like Medium/LinkedIn.

topics.title: Writing growth: iteration, peaks, and consistency
topics.summary: They compare viral-hit vs consistent-output paths, with Andy noting his “boom” came after dozens of posts and iterative learning, plus his preference to avoid newsletter deadlines.

topics.title: Strategic narrative framework: five core components
topics.summary: Andy lays out the structure: name the old/new game shift, name the stakes (winners/losers), name the object of the new game, define obstacles, then present the “magic gifts” (your solution) to overcome them.

topics.title: Hero’s journey parallels and making buyer the hero
topics.summary: They discuss how the framework relates to the hero’s journey but is more practical; Andy emphasizes the narrative shifts the buyer’s world and invites them to become the protagonist.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Eco, followed by Lenny transitioning back into an applied example.

topics.title: Case study: 360Learning narrative in practice
topics.summary: Andy walks through 360Learning’s shift from “collaborative learning” to a story about moving from top-down training to “upskill from within,” including stakes, buyer question framing, and obstacles.

topics.title: Business impact: marketing, sales, and product alignment
topics.summary: Andy describes outcomes he hears from CEOs: selling a movement instead of features, generating non-salesy content, and using the narrative as a product prioritization filter (e.g., Gong rejecting “opinion” features).

topics.title: Strong narrative example: Drift and conversational marketing
topics.summary: Andy highlights Drift’s “world of later (forms) to world of now” framing as a movement that differentiated them from many similar chatbots.

topics.title: Category creation vs movement and narrative
topics.summary: Andy argues category creation often over-focuses on naming, while the real differentiator is the underlying narrative; category labels are shorthand, but the movement story drives meaning and adoption.

topics.title: Where strategic narrative fits best (and where it doesn’t)
topics.summary: Andy explains the framework is most impactful for B2B enterprise tech with complex, fast-changing products and group buying, while many consumer products still benefit from spec/feature comparisons.

topics.title: Signals you need a narrative refresh
topics.summary: Andy shares common triggers: scaling beyond founder-led selling (often around Series B), expanding into new product lines that outgrow the old story, or pivoting due to market change.

topics.title: How to start: draft, test in calls, avoid templates
topics.summary: Andy recommends drafting the narrative structure and testing it qualitatively in real sales conversations (do prospects engage with the shift/stakes?), noting he’s skeptical of one-size-fits-all templates.
